title: Is our concept of the “self” real? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends what your concept of the self is. There’s a philosophical school of thought that the “self” is ever changing, not real, always different from moment to moment, and that there is no self. However, in the thousands of deep hypnosis cases I’ve examined, the 50 or so I’ve filmed, I’ve found that is accurate - but that the “self” that we think we know here, is not the same as the “self” that has incarnated many times both here on the planet and in some cases elsewhere. What people claim is that we bring about a third of our conscious energy to any given lifetime, about “two thirds” is always back home. That when we exit this stage, we return to that other two thirds, and can access all of that information, which includes all of our previous lifetimes. So in that instance alone, the concept of “self” doesn’t apply - because we seem to be talking about the “Conscious human self” and not about that conscious energy that we brought here that animates and informs who we are or become, or why we’re here and what lessons we’ve come to learn. However, that being said, even when the one third merges with the rest of us, that self is always learning, always changing, growing, etc. We go through many stages of learning - not in a hierarchical way but in a spiritual journey way. There is no hierarchy in this research - old souls and young souls are equal. But in terms of a person’s journey, they have many lives to lead, many lives to master. Many lessons to learn and many to teach. So the self which “seems eternal” with relation to our time frame, is not really “eternal” - there was a beginning point, and there will be a form of an “end point” - but suffice to say as we are here discussing this point, we’re in the midst of one of our many journeys.

Not in the slightest. It can’t possibly be, unless solipsism is actual. This is simply because the ‘self’ is what is considered to be ‘that which is considerate’ - that is to say ‘the self is what determines the appearance of the self and every aspect of its awareness’. So, if that perception is truly representative of reality then ‘reality’ is merely ‘what the self says’. If this is the case then all evidence is merely the impression the self gives itself of what it is doing and we might as well have a brain in a vat imagining it’s a brain in a vat. But then we have truth, right? Well, insofar as truth is necessarily tautological. However, here is the rub: if what we see as the ‘self’ is actually exactly what it is then we have a scenario where the description given by that self for itself would be absolutely definitive. In such a case what the self is would be literally self-evident in every sense. Where you are exactly what you believe yourself to be then you know yourself completely because that knowledge is the activity by which the self is structured. This sounds pretty good, though. I mean, I do know myself and cannot doubt it because that self would be doing the doubting. Yet with all due respect to Descartes there is absolutely no evidence for such an Echochamber unless that axiomatic awareness is, in fact, the sole basis of all belief that follows. Where ‘I AM’ is the necessary foundation of all philosophy there cannot be anything necessarily more than that. In short, if you are the judge of all things then all things are merely your judgement - because there is no reason but your own for them to be anything else. Nevertheless this logical conclusion is, in fact, quite paradoxical for a reason that is obvious from the nature of this question: such an absolute self could not be questioned. Where something is what it says itself to be it cannot concurrently ask what that is with any real uncertainty otherwise its own nature is nullified! ‘I AM’ cannot wonder ‘AM I?’, otherwise it is not in any coherent sense. Thus, a self-aware ‘self’ that exists by the determination of its own definition cannot be real, because if it were then the instability of identity would directly influence the world rendered in that reality. It may feel that way, but the most obvious insight available is that the world does not really respond to how we feel. If you convince yourself that everything really is the expression of your own existence then either way you do it to yourself, and that’s what really hurts…
